instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S0SW_LCD: What is PP3V3_S0SW_LCD? PP3V3_S0SW_LCD is a 3.3v power rail necessary to power the image circuitry on the screen. This is necessary to get a picture on the screen. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0SW_LCD</SIGNAL> keeps blowing inductor
threads.message:
Originally water damaged and backlight pins on socket and cable we're burnt, So replaced lvds connector, cable and backlight fuse and all was ok.

Tested for about 10mins and turned it off, then when I went to turn it back on no image. went to check <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0SW_LCD</SIGNAL> and L8304 was blown to bits. 
There was no short to ground on both sides, so I replaced it and it worked again.
Then I shut the lid and tossed the machine arround a bit and when I turned it on it just came up with a white screen. I then restarted machine and sure enough no image and L8304 was blown again. 

Any ideas?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0SW_LCD</SIGNAL> keeps blowing inductor
threads.message: Bad LCD cable or corrosion inside LCD.
